your aim is off. What you need to be focused on is where design and manufacturing is heading, namely Direct Digital Manufacturing (DDM).<br><br><br><blockquote>We are ...</blockquote> <span id="__w2_S4KtH3h_more"><a id="ld_tmwccl_737"></div><div class="CantAnswerActionBar ShowOnPass"><a class="AskToAnswerModalLink" id="__w2_tN2epc7_create_modal_link" target="_blank">Ask to Answer</a><span class="bullet"> • lazy" id="__w2_PNk9lv1_overflow_menu_contents"></div></div></div><div id="ld_dmnwxo_4475"><div id="__w2_l6k6jd1_add_answer_editor_wrapper"></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="feedback_wrapper" id="__w2_Ymwy1g7_feedback"></div><div id="ld_tmwccl_667"><div class="FeedMuteItemControls" id="__w2_fIJPoWL_mute_item_controls"><span id="ld_tmwccl_681"><div class="action_button" id="__w2_G3Ji4MA_mute_button">Mute <span class="item_name"><span id="ld_tmwccl_684"><span class="TopicNameSpan TopicName">Google</span></span></span></div></span><span id="ld_tmwccl_682"><a class="Downvote Button TwoStateButton Question secondary_action" href="#" action_target="{&quot;qid&quot;: 2432271, &quot;type&quot;: &quot;question&quot;}" action_click="QuestionDownvote" id="__w2_mYWvB1Y_button"><span id="__w2_mYWvB1Y_text">Downvote Question</span></a></span><span id="ld_tmwccl_683"><div class="action_button" id="__w2_Kcrr3QE_mute_button">Mute <span class="item_name">Question</span></div></span></div></div><div class="mute_item_overlay" id="__w2_aazTPzl_mute_item_overlay"><div class="cancel_mute_item_wrapper" id="__w2_aazTPzl_cancel_mute_item_wrapper"><div class="feed_mute_item" id="__w2_N0cQjx3_mute_item_wrapper"><div class="demote_item"><a class="lil_button promote_down" id="__w2_N0cQjx3_cancel_mute_item" target="_blank"></a></div></div></div></div><div class="feed_item_inner" id="__w2_Ymwy1g7_feed_item"><div id="ld_tmwccl_671"><div class="EventHeader">Answer written<span class="topic"><span class="bullet"> • </span></span><div class="TopicListItem" id="__w2_r95QfLN_topic_list_item"><div id="ld_tmwccl_687"><div class="hover_menu hidden white_bg show_nub" id="__w2_HnbMM8c_menu"><div class="hover_menu_contents" id="__w2_HnbMM8c_menu_contents"> </div></div><a class="TopicNameLink HoverMenu topic_name" href="/topic/Google" target="_blank" action_mousedown="TopicLinkClickthrough" id="__w2_HnbMM8c_link"><span class="name_text"><span id="ld_tmwccl_698"><span class="TopicNameSpan TopicName">Google</span></span></span></a></div></div><span class="bullet"> • </span><span class="timestamp"><a href="/Has-any-software-engineer-starting-his-career-in-companies-like-TCS-Infosys-Accenture-HCL-ever-made-it-to-the-biggies-like-Google-Microsoft-Facebook-Apple-Amazon-well-you-get-the-idea-and-what-has-been-their-approach-path-for-accomplishing-this/answer/Mauricio-Gómez-Rivero" target="_blank">9 Oct</a></span></div></div><div id="ld_tmwccl_672"><div class="QuestionText"><div><span id="ld_tmwccl_685"><a class="question_link" href="/Has-any-software-engineer-starting-his-career-in-companies-like-TCS-Infosys-Accenture-HCL-ever-made-it-to-the-biggies-like-Google-Microsoft-Facebook-Apple-Amazon-well-you-get-the-idea-and-what-has-been-their-approach-path-for-accomplishing-this" target="_blank" action_mousedown="QuestionLinkClickthrough" id="__w2_i9lh36t_link"><span class="question_text"><span id="ld_tmwccl_688"></span>Has any software engineer starting his career in companies like TCS, Infosys, Accenture, HCL ever made it to the biggies like Google, Microsoft, Facebook, Apple, Amazon, (well, you get the idea.) and what has been their approach/path for accomplishing this?</span></a></span></div></div></div><div id="ld_tmwccl_673"><div class="feed_item_answer answer_text"><div class="feed_item_answer_content answer_content"><div class="answer_user answer_user_inline"><div id="ld_ubqbbl_4215"><div class="AnswerHeader ContentHeader"><div id="ld_tuxefl_4443"><div class="hover_menu hidden white_bg show_nub" id="__w2_K8ADbTF_menu"><div class="hover_menu_contents" id="__w2_K8ADbTF_menu_contents"> </div></div><span class="photo_tooltip" id="__w2_K8ADbTF_link"><a href="/profile/Mauricio-Gómez-Rivero" id="__w2_DPMqbjL_link" target="_blank"><img class="profile_photo_img" src="https://qph.is.quoracdn.net/main-thumb-22544970-50-siopampwujmjpzapjxewjnvfdvjgtfth.jpeg" height="50" alt="Mauricio Gómez Rivero" width="50"></a><span id="ld_tuxefl_4446"></span></span></div><span class="feed_item_answer_user"><span id="ld_tuxefl_4444"><div class="hover_menu hidden white_bg show_nub" id="__w2_uQo1J04_menu"><div class="hover_menu_contents" id="__w2_uQo1J04_menu_contents"> </div></div><a class="user" href="/profile/Mauricio-Gómez-Rivero" action_mousedown="UserLinkClickthrough" id="__w2_uQo1J04_link" target="_blank">Mauricio Gómez Rivero</a><span class="IdentitySig ActorNameSig IdentityNameSig" id="__w2_PP56sB9_bio">, <span id="__w2_PP56sB9_link"><span class="IdentitySig ActorNameSig IdentityNameSig" id="__w2_PP56sB9_sig"><span class="expanded_q_text" id="__w2_K0vXReY_text_snip"><span id="__w2_K0vXReY_text_snip_content">works for Google</span></span></span></span></span></span></span><div class="credibility_facts"><div id="ld_tuxefl_4445"><div class="CredibilityFact">97.2k Views</div></div></div></div></div></div><div><div id="ld_ubqbbl_4216"></div><div class="Expandable SimpleToggle Toggle AnswerInFeedExpandable AnswerExpandable" id="__w2_mIVEFsF__truncated"><div id="ld_ubqbbl_4217"><div class="truncated_q_text TruncatedQText TruncatedAnswer" id="__w2_uR3iDvg_truncated">I worked for two IT service companies, TCS and Softtek, at some point in my career and now I work for Google.<br><br>These are the main issues I would expect a person coming from the IT service industry:<br><br><ul><li>...</li></ul> <span id="__w2_uR3iDvg_more"><a class="more_link" target="_blank">(more)</a></span><span class="hidden" id="__w2_uR3iDvg_loading"><span class="loading">Loading…</span></span> </div></div></div><div class="Expandable SimpleToggle Toggle AnswerInFeedExpandable AnswerExpandable hidden" id="__w2_mIVEFsF__expanded"><div id="ld_mmfblf_256"><div class="ExpandedQText ExpandedAnswer" id="__w2_svZphNs_expanded">I worked for two IT service companies, TCS and Softtek, at some point in my career and now I work for Google.<br><br>These are the main issues I would expect a person coming from the IT service industry:<br><br><ul><li>IT service companies hire people based on experience and knowledge rather than the fundamental skills like problem solving skills (the more qualified you look the more they can bill the client, right?) and the bar is pretty low. Also, it is very common that good people don't stay as SWE for long time and get moved up to management so that they can get a higher compensation. Therefore, you rarely work with a person who reached his top as SWE. Thus, your expectations of what a good software engineer is are not realistic.</li><li>Software engineers in the IT service companies rely a lot on the use of existing solutions to solve problems and accepting any inefficiency (e.g. let's solve this problem by scheduling a cron job that calls a unix script that runs a java application that pushes data to a jms queue which gets consumed by another java application that stores the data to an oracle database, then let's some BI, like crystal reports, tool to get a nice email sent to the final destination). Whereas engineers in top tech companies focus on the ideal solution to the problem, then use any existing solution that fits in the ideal solution and finally build whatever is missing (either from scratch or enhancing an existing solution); yes, they make trade-offs some times.</li></ul><br>In short, if not clear, you don't work with the best SWEs and your approach to solve problems is different from what top tech companies expect. These bring some issues which come up easily during an interview and make you look bad even if you are a potential good candidate. The issues I refer to are things like coming up with suboptimal solutions and think they are okay (e.g. you saw the solution provided somewhere in your current job and never criticized it), not being able to explain in depth how some parts of your solution work (e.g. you use a LRU cache but have no clue how it gets implemented), etc.<br><br><b>What can you do to improve and get a job in a top tech company?</b><br><i><u>Re-train your brain.</u></i><br><br>Forget what you know and start from scratch. Read some computer science books and also do programming competitions if possible or at least try to solve problems on your spare time. You will start seeing a different world in the work you do and you will ask yourself why you didn't do it earlier. After some time, when you talk to your workmates about your solutions you will notice that they can barely follow you even though it looks obvious to you; at this point you know you have to switch to a different job.<br><br>This worked for me mainly because I've always liked computer science and problem solving stuff but I never prioritized them (I'd rather spent time studying for java certifications).<div id="ld_mmfblf_257"><div class="ContentFooter AnswerFooter" id="__w2_j34PRje_content_footer"><span id="ld_mmfblf_258"><a class="answer_permalink" href="/Has-any-software-engineer-starting-his-career-in-companies-like-TCS-Infosys-Accenture-HCL-ever-made-it-to-the-biggies-like-Google-Microsoft-Facebook-Apple-Amazon-well-you-get-the-idea-and-what-has-been-their-approach-path-for-accomplishing-this/answer/Mauricio-Gómez-Rivero" action_mousedown="AnswerPermalinkClickthrough" id="__w2_lqnLIGx_link">Written 9 Oct</a></span><span class="bullet"> • </span><a class="AnswerVoterListModalLink VoterListModalLink" href="/api/mobile_expanded_voter_list?type=answer&amp;key=8m5pCfuUCZZ" id="__w2_XJEuNsC_modal_link">View Upvotes</a><span id="ld_mmfblf_259"></span></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="ld_tmwccl_674"><div style="height: 0px; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; clear: both; display: block;"></div><div shirtless but get up before your parents in the morning. id="ld_oyymqg_1140"><div class="truncated_q_text TruncatedQText TruncatedAnswer" id="__w2_P3vNWmK_truncated"><div class="truncated_thumbnail_holder"><div class="qtext_image_wrapper"><img id="__w2_VuELgY7__truncated"><div id="ld_avcqae_1984"><div class="truncated_q_text TruncatedQText TruncatedAnswer" id="__w2_nYMzvsQ_truncated"><div class="truncated_thumbnail_holder"><div class="qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="landscape qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" src="https://qph.is.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-cc8ae7fc4b99159453adad98596afa1e?convert_to_webp=true" master_src="https://qph.is.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-ad65ffc77e1966fb0d85eec5286a5c14?convert_to_webp=true" master_w="1065" master_h="960"></div></div>I went from 100% junk food diet to a healthy and balanced diet. This is my 3 year natural transformation:<br><br><br><br>A major contributor to making this switch permanent is strenght training. Strength train... <span id="__w2_nYMzvsQ_more"><a class="more_link" target="_blank">(more)</a></span><span class="hidden" id="__w2_nYMzvsQ_loading"><span class="loading">Loading…</span></span> </div></div></div><div class="Expandable SimpleToggle Toggle AnswerInFeedExpandable AnswerExpandable hidden" id="__w2_VuELgY7__expanded"><div id="ld_zowaxu_439"><div class="ExpandedQText ExpandedAnswer" id="__w2_U9HQYRl_expanded">I went from 100% junk food diet to a healthy and balanced diet. This is my 3 year natural transformation:<br><br><div class="qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="landscape qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" src="https://qph.is.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-cc8ae7fc4b99159453adad98596afa1e?convert_to_webp=true" master_src="https://qph.is.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-ad65ffc77e1966fb0d85eec5286a5c14?convert_to_webp=true" master_w="1065" master_h="960"></div><br><br>A major contributor to making this switch permanent is strenght training. Strength training does not equal physical exercise. Training requires you to set a goal, which is usually getting stronger, leaner and pushing more weight for more reps.<br><br>If you do this, you will notice that the only wayt to achieve these goals you set is only by a healthy and balanced diet. <br><br>It is a long journey, as you will never be strong enough, or lean enough because you will always set higher goals.<div id="ld_zowaxu_440"><div Toggle AnswerInFeedExpandable AnswerExpandable hidden" id="__w2_n6XrVnr__expanded"><div id="ld_rmonap_17"><div class="ExpandedQText ExpandedAnswer" id="__w2_Ugt4v26_expanded">As <span class="qlink_container"><a href="/profile/Anurag-Sharma-88">Anurag Sharma</a></span> said, unless you have a magic wand or photoshoping skills it won't happen.<br><br>It may be due to lack of information on the subject that causes you to think that - 1 month of gym exercise will make this (below)<br><div class="qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="landscape qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" src="https://qph.is.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-c36603dd3f4c69abbaaba12346a86dbc?convert_to_webp=true" master_src="https://qph.is.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-6e2108afbb66577986ee60c3f3d42938?convert_to_webp=true" master_w="720" master_h="540"></div><br><br>Into this (below)<br><div class="qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="landscape qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" src="https://qph.is.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-db7a3202205c71230036af8b147c01ab?convert_to_webp=true" more than 10kg of lean muscle a year is a bit much; and here you talk about the same in a month. What exactly do you think happens inside a gym? - Entire genetic remodeling?<br><br>On a sidenote if only weight gain is all you need, then eating a load of high GI carbs will make you put on some weight. If a broad chest is your requirement - then a heavy gym workout for a month will take you closer to your goal, but still may not be upto your expectations.<br><br>You can still get a lean body by focusing on calisthenics without needing gym equipment.<div id="ld_rmonap_18"><div class="ContentFooter AnswerFooter" id="__w2_QOsQHNP_content_footer"><span id="ld_rmonap_19"><a
